g.text: , grainfall laminations developed on dune slip faces
which may have formed on low-relief aeolian sand sheets or around the flanks of dunes (Fig.Â
lateral and vertical stacking of fluvial and aeolian facies indicates that the lowermost Triassic Liujiagou Formation
was deposited in an environment where ephemeral sandy braided rivers interacted and alternated with aeolian
processes. Comparable mixed fluvial-aeolian deposits have been identified in the Jurassic Tianchihe Formation of
and in the Early Triassic of the western European basins
The late Early Triassic Heshanggou Formation is dominated by shallow lacustrine deposits, characterized
by cycles of siltstones and/or mudstones interbedded with a few thin fine-medium grained sandstone layers.
Bioturbation in the Heshanggou Formation becomes stronger from the bottom to top, suggesting biological
recovery after the extinction near the PTB
). Diverse trace fossils and the bioturbation index
Sunjiagou and Heshanggou formations are summarized in Fig.Â
Two detrital zircons yield youngest ages of 269
the Sunjiagou Formation (sample 2015BDSJG-1, Supplementary TableÂ S6) and the Liujiagou Formation (sample
2015BDLJG-1, Supplementary TableÂ S6). They constrain the age of the Sunjiagou Formation as Guadalupianâ
Lopingian and the Liujiagou Formation as lowermost Triassic. Combined with previous biostratigraphic data and
the mass extinction at the uppermost Sunjiagou Formation, as well as the sedimentary environmental transition
from the Sunjiagou Formation to Liujiagou Formation, these dates convincingly constrain the terrestrial PTB in
North China. Moreover, the detrital zircon age results from the Sunjiagou and Liujiagou formations in this study
show nearly the same characteristics of age groups and peaks (Supplementary Fig.Â S2). Combined with similar age
populations of detrital zircons from the Late Permian-Early Triassic strata nearby
to infer that the Sunjiagou and Liujiagou formations in northern Shanxi, North China share the same source area,
originating from the YinshanâYanshan Orogenic Belt and Northern Qinling Orogen.
Stratigraphic overview showing the contact between the Sunjiagou and Liujiagou formations. White
triangles denote upward fining cycles in the Sunjiagou Formation. Dotted line denotes base of the PTB interval.
E. Abbreviations: Fm, Formation; PTB, Permian-Triassic boundary;
Z.C.Z created this figure using CorelDRAW14. Photo credit: Y.Q.L.
Typical features of the Sunjiagou Formation. (
the lower parts of channel point bars overlying a sharp erosion surface on overbank mudstones. (
bar deposits comprising laterally accreted beds of sandstone and mudstone. Photo credit: Y.Q.L.
